Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Computer-Aided Grading, Feedback, and Assignment Creating in Massive Online Programming Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) are widely regarded as a
revolutionary innovation; however, traditional instructional
techniques do not scale to MOOCs with tens of thousands of students.
This project aims to design a set of algorithmic tools to partially
automate three of the most basic instructional processes - grading
assignments, giving students personalized feedback, and creating new
assignments - in MOOCs that teach computer programming. Such tools
have the potential to significantly raise the productivity of
instructors in these courses, and give students a far more effective
educational experience than what they currently receive. They can also
guide the development of future MOOCs on programming, and play a role
in making the MOOC model reach its full potential.

The algorithms developed in this project draw on ideas from several
different areas of computing. They leverage advances in automated
reasoning about software like automatically finding bugs in
student code and suggesting fixes, and exploit statistical learning
techniques that mine databases of previously-completed assignments and
infer aggregate statistics about a class. Finally, the research has a
dimension of human computation, for instance seeding logical and
statistical analysis techniques with data obtained through peer
evaluation. These methods apply to any programming course; however,
the investigators will evaluate them by deploying them in a specific
MOOC on Python programming that they teach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was one of the early efforts on algorithmic tools forMOOCs.  On the scientific front, the intellectual merit outcomes ofour project include the following.

* We developed a method for automatically grading programmingassignments from a popular MOOC on Python programming designed byco-PIs Warren and Rixner. The method uses a combination of lightweightprogram analysis and statistical machine learning to generate scoresfor student-written code. A paper on this topic was published at theInternationaI Conference on Data Mining (ICDM), 2014.


* We developed a system for visualizing the behavior ofstudent-written Python programs. The system has been integrated intoCodeSkulptor, a browser-based implementation of Python that is used inRixner and Warren's course. A paper on this topic was published atSIGCSE 2014.

* We performed a study that shed light on how to incentivize studentsin MOOCs to perform higher-quality peer evaluation. The primaryquestion in the study was whether "grading the graders" -- a schemewhere students know that the scores/reviews that they produce as partof peer evaluation are visible to other students, and where studentsget to evaluate the evaluations written by others --- improves thequality of peer evaluation. A paper on this topic was published at theWorld Wide Web Conference (WWW), 2015.

* We developed a method for automatic, data-driven test casegeneration for automatically grading programming assignments.  Themethod generates test sets for a programming problem from an existingcollection of student solutions for that problem, and demonstrates theeffectiveness of the proposed method in online programming courseassessments.  A paper on this topic was published at the ACMConference on Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education(ITiCSE), July 2016.

* We developed a system that helps introductory students learn how totest software. A paper on this topic was published at the ACMConference on Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education(ITiCSE), July 2017.

* We developed a data-driven program synthesis method suited toautomatically giving feedback to students in large online programmingclasses. The method uses a large corpus of preexisting programs toguide a search for fixes or completions for a student-writtenbuggy/incomplete program. A paper on this topic is in submission.
* Finally, the project partially supported the development of a methodfor automatic discovery and debugging of proofs of program correctnessusing a database of pre-existing proofs. The method is useful forstudents learning to reason about correctness of programs. This workhas led to a Masters thesis (to be defended in December 2017), and isbeing prepared for submission.

The broader impacts of our project include:

1) Training and professional development of graduate researchers.  The award supported a two PhD students (Terry Tang andAfsaneh Rahbar).

2) Computer science education. Tools developed in the project havebeen deployed in a popular MOOC run by two of the PIs, and shown topositively influence learning outcomes.

3) Software. The award supported the development of several softwaresystems. Some of these systems have been deployed in a MOOC that twoof the PIs run.

4) Workshops. Chaudhuri co-chaired the 2nd Workshop on ProgrammingLanguage Technology for Massive Open Online Courses (PLOOC); Rixnerwas an invited speaker in the first edition of this workshop. Thisworkshop brings together researchers who are from a variety of areas,but believe that programming language tools can potentially make MOOCsmore productive than they are today.
